I like this game. I say that first because this review is mainly going to be things I think could be improved as opposed to things that I like. It's a fun game that has plenty of room to grow. I probably put 8 hours into the game past the last story objective before I realized that I had completed the current story content because the game is just that fun. Going down the list of things I think need to be improved:

1) The game is VERY similar to Stardew Valley. I streamed this to a friend and he literally thought I was playing modded Stardew. That's not inherently bad, Stardew valley is a phenomenal game, but if I wanted to play Stardew Valley I'd play Stardew Valley. A lot of the game is spent farming in a near identical way to Stardew, and I frequently found mechanics the game presented familiar. The game has an interesting foundation (there's a lot more to the game than just owning a tavern story-wise) and I feel like they should work off of that. 
Let me hire stage performers to play at my tavern. Let me host guild meetings or adventurer parties. Let me make magical brews to help people. The game presents itself in a medieval fantasy setting, yet it feels like I'm running a rural bar in Montana. Give me more TAVERN related things to do, not more SIMULATOR things to do.

2) There are some QOL features that are really needed. Like, you can't make changes to your kitchen or work areas while the tavern is open. Let me manage work spaces while the tavern is open. Automation of certain systems is also a huge necessity. Obviously they can't let you automize EVERYTHING but it gets to a points where if you aren't doing some things multiple times a day, like cooking food or farming, you'll immediately start to have problems. 

3) They need to expand the brewing mechanics of the game. Most of the brewing you can do is essentially just adding to drinks together to get a better, more expensive drink. I think adding some sort of alchemy or magic element to brewing in the later game would be really fun. Again, this is a FANTASY setting. I wanna do cool magic stuff. 

Overall, very fun game, but don't buy if you're expecting a fully completed, 200+ hour experience like other simulator games. This one needs more time in the oven, and that's okay.

So first things first. Travellers Rest is in EA... which means some things are still baking.

The primary thing being the story. There IS a story here, but there's not much here yet. I've been playing many hours since the last time that I actually had a quest.

So for the time being, if you are wanting a story give the game a minute unless you wanna support it early. But if you are down for a relaxing game where you manage a tavern, pick it up. In that respect I have very few complaints about the game. There are some tweaks here and there that I'd really REALLY like to see, but overall the game is really good as a management sim alone.

You can farm for your ingredients, raise and butcher livestock, have a basement full of alcohol, and eventually it's more than a bar and you actually have rooms people can rent.

For now the main goal of the game is just to improve your tavern. Unlocking all the various things you can to make managing things cheaper take quite a bit of time. So for a good long while you won't be short on things to do. Eventually you will get the ability to build onto your tavern and make it bigger as well.

It does fall short on the decorating... there's some really fun decor in the game but for the most part it feels like most decor runs along a certain theme and mixing and matching gets a little difficult. None the less the decorating is still a fun aspect of the game.

Warning, because I know there are those that find annoyance in this, this IS a game where save happens when you sleep. There is no auto save or manual save. You save when you sleep. You character also has to sleep. If you are up past 3am you will pass out and lose several hours the next day.

That being said.... there is no stamina bar which is one of my favorite things because I can just run around all day and do whatever the fuck I want.

Eventually you will unlock employees and they are very easy to manage. My only real complaint here is that you will get an employee that manages you rooms, they can also refill candles and start the fire in your tavern. Problem is that the employee spends 4 silver everytime they refill a candle and there's no way for them to pull from candles you have made. I'd love to see this changed because this employee is incredibly under utilized by me because I don't want to pay for candles when I have hundreds of them.

Animals are easy to care for. They CAN get sick, but so far I've been able to avoid that happening. Most things feel balanced... other than pigs. It feels like it costs too much to make slop and they are by far the least worth it of the animals you can get. They don't produce anything, they just exist to be slaughtered. At least all the other animals I can butcher and they give a by product. So if I have to buy their feed it's fine.

There's pets! Which is wonderful and there's diversity! You don't have to own all animals but they have enough variety that there's something for everyone. Tarantula, fish, snake, lizard, frog, hamster, cat, dogs, birds. There's so many and it's wonderful. I plan on having all of them.

My only complaint when it comes to fishing is the traps. The traps are single use. They will catch two things and then be destroyed. At this point they just aren't worth building because they can also catch trash. It's far easier to just buy stuff like lobster and shrimp from the vendor.

Again though, overall the game is a great management sim that gives a decent amount of creativity when it comes to decorating. I think I had... maybe 10 hours before I started this new save after a long time of not playing? So I'd say that around 50 hours is where I've started feeling like I've hit the end of the content. At this point I'm just trying to expand my bar and actually decorate it and that's the real extent of my gameplay besides leveling up so I can unlock more cooking recipes (that's another bummer, you can only unlock 2 recipes per level of your tavern, I wish we got more). Other than those things I've really truly run out of things to do. Oh and I've got a handful of fish I haven't caught.

Far as I'm concerned though that's a lot of content for an EA game. There's a whole lot to do here, a lot of chill fun to be had. I definitely recommend the game in it's current state, again, unless you are looking for story.

The game is charming. Delightful design, music, and sound design. So it's a pleasure to look at and listen to as well.

[b]Strengths[/b]

A Wonderfully Cozy Atmosphere

The art style is warm, inviting, and full of charm. Combined with the gentle soundtrack and the lively glow of your tavern in the evening, the game creates an atmosphere that feels as comforting as sitting in a real inn on a rainy night.

Rewarding Progression and Crafting Systems

Progression is smooth and deeply satisfying. Brewing unique drinks, cooking meals, farming ingredients, expanding your inn, unlocking new tools, and decorating your tavern all blend together into a loop that feels rich and rewarding.

Satisfying Tavern Management

Running your tavern feels personal. You serve guests, keep the place tidy, upgrade furniture, customize rooms, and steadily turn your small inn into a bustling gathering place. Watching your effort transform the building into something truly yours is one of the game‚Äôs greatest joys.

Relaxing Yet Engaging Gameplay Loop

There is always something to do, yet nothing feels stressful. You can choose your own pace, focus on the activities you enjoy, and slowly build the kind of inn that matches your creativity and playstyle.

Active Development and Constant Improvements

The developers clearly care about this game. Updates are frequent, thoughtful, and packed with improvements that make the world feel bigger and more vibrant.

[b]Weaknesses[/b]

Some Repetitive Daily Tasks

Cleaning, serving, and restocking can become repetitive in the late game, especially during longer sessions. While staff helps ease the workload, some actions could benefit from more variety or automation.

Early Game Starts Slowly

The opening hours can feel a bit slow for players who prefer fast progression. Once more systems unlock, however, the game becomes much more engaging.

Management Depth Could Go Further

While the tavern gameplay is fun, players who love deep strategy may wish for more advanced management features or more diverse guest behaviors.

Comparison to Stardew Valley

If you enjoy Stardew Valley, there is a very good chance you will love Traveller‚Äôs Rest as well  but for different reasons.

Despite a few small shortcomings, Traveller‚Äôs Rest is a delightful and highly engaging tavern life sim with an atmosphere that is almost impossible to resist.
